RISK MANAGEMENT PLAN - SANFORD M. ANDERSON WATER TREATMENT PLANT



EXECUTIVE SUMMARY



City of Inglewood Sanford M. Anderson Water Treatment Plant has established a Risk Management Plan according to Federal EPA's (40 CFR Part 68) and California Accidental Release Prevention (CalARP) regulations to enhance already existing safety and emergency action programs.  City of Inglewood is extremely cautious in the handling of all chemicals and is very diligent about safety for its employees, the communities where its facilities are located, and customers.  City of Inglewood staff is well trained and utilizes modern equipment to monitor its facilities to provide safeguards, while effectively employing these useful chemicals.  These chemicals play an important role in water treatment, enabling everyone to lead healthier lives.





Accidental Release Prevention and Emergency Response Policies



City of Inglewood has an emergency action plan in effect to handle potential emergencies at this facility.  This plan was designed to meet the following objectives:



1.) To save lives.

2.) To minimize and avoid injuries.

3.) To protect the environment.

4.) To minimize property damage.



The Emergency Action Plan provides notification procedures, evacuation routes, chlorine health hazards and mitigation procedures that will be implemented to respond effectively to emergency situations that may arise at the facility.  This Plan is reviewed and updated periodically and has been reviewed and updated to ensure compliance with the PSM, RMP and CalARP regulations.





Stationary Source and Regulated Substance



The City of Inglewood Sanford M. Anderson Water Treatment Plant maintains chlorine on-site for use in disinfecting water treated by the plant.  There is a single chlorination building located at the facility housing the chlorine containers.  Chlorine gas is supplied under vacuum from the containers to the chlorinators which regulate the chlorine feed.  Downstream of the vacu

um regulators installed on each container, the system is operated under vacuum as a safety measure.  The vacuum is created at the chlorinators by water flow through a set of injectors.  In case of a break, the vacuum regulators close automatically minimizing the quantity of chlorine gas that may escape from the system.  Also, the entire system is connected to the gaseous side of the container.  This is also an important safety feature.  Chlorine detectors are provided for the chlorination building to maximize safety and minimize release of any chlorine gas from the storage building into the atmosphere.  The detectors alarm locally and remotely. 



The City of Inglewood Sanford M. Anderson Water Treatment Plant also maintains 19% aqueous ammonia on-site for use in disinfecting water treated by the plant.  The Aqueous Ammonia System is situated in a containment area inside the fence line of the plant.  Aqueous ammonia is supplied from the Aqueous Ammonia Storage tank to the injection point.  A Vapor Diffuser is used as a safety measure to minimize the possibility of ammonia vapors being released into the atmosphere.  Pressure switches are placed downstream of the pumps as a safety feature.  If the pressure rises above or below the operating parameters, the pumps will automatically shut down.





Accidental Release Prevention Program and Chemical-Specific Prevention Steps



City of Inglewood Sanford M. Anderson Water Treatment Plant has PSM and RMP programs in place to manage the handling of chlorine and aqueous ammonia.  The programs include strict requirements for written operating procedures, personnel training, contractor safety, equipment maintenance, incident investigation, process hazard analysis, management of change and periodic review or audit of the implementation of program elements.  Management of change element addresses proper implementation of system updates to ensure that all changes are reviewed properly by knowledgeable persons, all engineering do

cuments and operating procedures reflect the change, and personnel are trained on the change.   Process Safety Management also requires a pre-startup safety review to ensure that the system is properly reviewed before it is put back into service after a major change.  



In addition to PSM and RMP, common industry standards, policies, and procedures are strictly followed.  Also, common practices outlined by the Chlorine Institute are implemented in system design and day-to-day system operation.  





Five Year Accident History



The five-year accident history (April 2015 to April 2020) for the City of Inglewood Sanford M. Anderson Water Treatment Plant reveals that there were no reportable accidents during this period.





Planned Changes to Improve Safety



When implementation of the PSM and RMP compliance program was initiated, several studies were conducted that included recommendations to enhance safety.  Those recommendations have been addressed,  Recent review of the system and associated safety programs has not identified any additional safety related improvements.
